abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Public Sector
            Modernization Project for Jamaica was satisfactory with
            likely sustainability, substantial institutional development
            impact, and satisfactory performances by both the Bank and
            the Borrower.  By request from the government, the
            privatization objective and component was eliminated from
            the project.  Factors generally subject to government
            control included: macroeconomic performance, resistance to
            change, and counterpart funding delays.  Factors generally
            subject to implementing agency control included: delays in
            recruiting qualified staff, delays in implementing the
            procurement component, and limited progress in implementing
            the Human Resources and Financial Management Information
            Systems  (HRMIS/FMIS).  Lessons learned include the
            following:  Macroeconomic stability is critical to the
            sustainability of the public sector modernization process.
            Greater managerial and financial autonomy is essential to
            realize the full benefits of modernization. Aligning of
            incentives is critical to support long-term sustainability.
            Improve internal accounting systems is essential for
            informed decision-making.  Avoid delays in recruiting
            qualified managerial and technical staff.
